docs.lead_paragraph: Congress Reaches a Deal To Rewrite Bankruptcy Law Congressional negotiators have reached agreement on a bill that would rewrite the bankruptcy law, making it harder for people to escape their debts. The agreement, a victory for the nation's credit card companies and other lenders, came after members of a conference committee reached a compromise on the wording of an abortion-rights provision. The bill, which has passed both houses of Congress, now appears destined for final approval in the House and Senate, and the White House has suggested that President Bush will sign it. [Page A1.]

docs.lead_paragraph: One of the most traumatic experiences a family can suffer -- the death of a child -- is often worsened by ineffective health care that fails to address the physical, emotional or spiritual needs of the patient and family members, a report released today found. The report, written by a committee of experts from the Institute of Medicine, said that compassionate and reliable care intended to help families prepare for a child's death ''has not usually been a priority'' for health care providers, researchers or the public.

headline.main: Health System Adds to Pain Of Losing Child, Panel Says

docs.abstract: Report by Institute of Medicine experts says death of a child, most traumatic experience family can suffer, is often worsened by ineffective health care that fails to address physical, emotional or spiritual needs of patients and family members; says compassionate care to help families prepare for child's death has not usually been priority for health care providers; 55,000 children aged one to 19 died in US in 1999; half of childhood deaths occur in infancy, with injury major cause of death among older children and teenagers (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Who Really Cooks the Books?,'' by Warren E. Buffett (Op-Ed, July 24), is most provocative, but he misses one long overlooked way to bring abusive C.E.O.'s down to earth.
docs.abstract: Gerald C Meyers letter says Warren Buffett's July 24 Op-Ed on corporate scandal is most provocative but overlooks key way to bring abusive executives down to earch: requiring them to report as income value of their expensive perks, from fancy airplanes to country clubs and luxury family travel (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: With doctors complaining about rising malpractice insurance premiums, President Bush called today for a major overhaul of the nation's medical liability system, including legislation to cap compensation for pain and suffering at $250,000 in successful malpractice suits. ''Health care costs are up because docs are worried about getting sued,'' the president told an audience of 1,700 health care professionals in a sweltering gymnasium at High Point University here.

headline.main: Bush Urges a Cap on Medical Liability

docs.abstract: Pres Bush calls for major overhaul of medical liability system, including capping compensation for pain and suffering at $250,000 in successful malpractice suits; says costs are up 'because docs are worried about getting sued'; comments during appearance in North Carolina to raise funds for Elizabeth Dole's campaign for US Senate; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: One in every six American children is Hispanic, but it's hard to find them in the research on child health. According to the Journal of the American Medical Association, Latino children suffer from a disproportionate number of health problems that have been poorly studied. Diabetes is on the rise, and Latino boys have the highest rates of obesity among young people, but researchers don't know why. They also don't know why Puerto Rican children have rates of asthma higher than those in any other region. Many of the statistics pose mysteries that go beyond the fact that Hispanic children are less likely to be covered by health insurance than are children in other ethnic groups. For instance, Latino children who are hospitalized with limb fractures receive less pain medication than do white or African-American youths. No one seems to know why, and data is hard to collect because Hispanic children are often included in the categories of white, black or ''other'' in medical research. Many researchers also ignore these children and their parents by excluding non-English-speakers from their studies.
docs.abstract: Editorial calls for much more research on health problems of Hispanic children

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''More May Not Mean Better in Health Care, Studies Find'' (front page, July 21) couldn't have come at a better time. Health expenditures are accelerating again after nearly 20 years.

headline.main: Health Care, in the Right Doses

docs.lead_paragraph: House and Senate negotiators agreed late tonight on the details of legislation that would give President Bush authority to make international trade deals that could be approved or rejected -- but not amended -- by Congress. The issue has been one of the White House's top legislative priorities this year, and should the package agreed to by the House and Senate negotiators tonight win final approval from both chambers it would be a big victory for Mr. Bush.

headline.main: House and Senate Reach Initial Deal on Trade Powers for Bush

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Research like that presented in ''More May Not Mean Better in Health Care, Studies Find'' (front page, July 21) is all too often misused as a rationalization for policies that deny access to care and choice of treatments.

headline.main: Health Care, in the Right Doses

docs.lead_paragraph: CINEMARK INC., Plano, Tex., a chain of movie theaters, postponed its initial public offering indefinitely because of market conditions. Cinemark had planned to raise $199 million through the sale of 11.1 million shares. CORNING INC., Corning, N.Y., the largest maker of optical fiber and cable, said it had canceled plans to build a plant in Oklahoma City and to expand another in Concord, N.C. Termination expenses were included in Corning's second-quarter loss of $370 million, or 39 cents a share.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The Senate's vote to allow Americans to import prescription drugs from Canada (news article, July 18) only appears to be an act of political bravery. A real act of bravery would be to bring Canadian drug prices to the pharmacies of America.
docs.abstract: Letter from Richard Kirsch (Citizen Action of NY) on July 18 article urges Congress to defy drug lobby and authorize Medicare to demand same low prescription drug prices Veterans Administration and Canadian government get
